docs.lead_paragraph: Reader responds to an article about
docs.snippet: Reader responds to an article about

docs.lead_paragraph: Although President  Obama and many Democrats promised during the health care reform debate that "if you like your health plan, you can keep it," the health insurance plans that are now offered by small businesses probably will not survive the transition to a regulated marketplace. The Obama administration acknowledged this on Monday, when it proposed regulations for determining what insurance plans can remain exempt from market reforms. And while participants in those plans will probably be grateful for it, business owners may be less sanguine about the outcome.

headline.main: Small Firms May Not Keep Current Health Plans After White House Decision

docs.abstract: It seems reasonable to assume that as plans lose their grandfathered status and are required to adopt more stringent patient protections, they will become more expensive for employee and employer alike.
docs.snippet: It seems reasonable to assume that as plans lose their grandfathered status and are required to adopt more stringent patient protections, they will become more expensive for employee and employer alike.

docs.lead_paragraph: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline.main: Tuesday Reading: The Status of Unemployment Benefits

docs.abstract: An update on unemployment benefits, the consequences of not having health insurance and other consumer-focused items from Tuesday's Times.
docs.snippet: An update on unemployment benefits, the consequences of not having health insurance and other consumer-focused items from Tuesday's Times.

docs.lead_paragraph: Senate Democrats are exploring whether to eliminate an extra $25 a week in unemployment benefits,  part of the economic stimulus legislation passed in 2009, as a way to cut costs and attract Republican votes for a stalled package of tax breaks, tax increases on the affluent and safety-net spending.

headline.main: Senate Democrats Might Change Jobs Bill

docs.abstract: Senate Democrats are considering whether to get rid of extra unemployment benefits, with a test vote set for Wednesday.
docs.snippet: Senate Democrats are considering whether to get rid of extra unemployment benefits, with a test vote set for Wednesday.

headline.main: What's the Penalty for Not Having Insurance?

docs.abstract: In 2016, the financial penalty for failing to have health insurance will be $695 for an individual or 2.5 percent of household income, whichever is greater.
docs.snippet: In 2016, the financial penalty for failing to have health insurance will be $695 for an individual or 2.5 percent of household income, whichever is greater.

docs.lead_paragraph: A requirement of the new health care law that insurers spend more of each premium dollar to benefit consumers may chase some companies from the market, officials say.

headline.main: Seeing Threat to Individual Policies, State Officials Urge a Gradual Route to Change
headline.print_headline: Seeing Threat to Individual Policies, State Officials Urge a Gradual Route to Change

docs.lead_paragraph: Ninety-two percent of Rwanda is covered by a national health plan, and the premiums are $2 a year.

docs.lead_paragraph: The clemency board says William Macumber is innocent, but Arizona’s governor has refused to discuss freeing him.
